title-group.article-title: Note-Taking Techniques for Students With Disabilities
title-group.subtitle: A Systematic Review of the Research

abstract.p: This article provides a synthesis of note-taking research among students with learning disabilities or other high-incidence disabilities. A search of the professional literature between 1980 and 2010 yielded nine intervention studies, which were evaluated either in terms of effect size or percentage of nonoverlapping data. The studies examined three different note-taking techniques used by students during lectures and included 125 students of varying disabilities. Findings revealed that students who used note-taking techniques were effective at increasing scores on measures of achievement and the quality and quantity of notes recorded. Limitations and implications of note-taking techniques for content-area classrooms are discussed.

body.p: For secondary students with learning disabilities (LD), learning during lectures has taken an elevated level of importance in recent years as more of these students must now pass end-of-the-year state tests to advance in courses, graduate from high school, and become prepared for college or postsecondary institutions (Deshler, Schumaker, Bui, & Vernon, 2006; Scruggs, Mastropieri, & Okolo, 2008). Newman, Wagner, Cameto, Knokey, and Shaver (2010) reported that approximately 45% of youth with disabilities now attend postsecondary education institutions within 4 years of graduation from high school, with the largest majority of those students being students with LD. For students with LD and other high-incidence disabilities, this means that they must not only have access to the general education curriculum but also be able to effectively use many different academic learning skills, such as note- taking, to comprehend the content from their classes and pass rigorous academic courses (Deshler et al., 2006). In many of these content-area courses, lectures comprise a major portion of students’ time (i.e., typically 28% [Johnson, 2008] to 50% [Putnam, Deshler, & Schumaker, 1993]), and note-taking is perhaps the most crucial skill used to assist students to understand and learn content during lectures.

Recording notes allows students to actively follow the lecture, consciously select important from unimportant information, and rephrase lecture points in their own words (Steimle, Brdiczka, & Mühlhäuser, 2009). When students use note-taking skills during lectures, they increase their encoding of lecture content (Shrager & Mayer, 1989). Recording notes not only helps students recall information from lectures, but according to Kobayashi (2005), note-taking among K–12 students facilitates their understanding of lecture content, which, in turn, enhances retention of information. In addition, because teachers frequently construct tests from information found in their lectures (Putnam et al., 1993), taking notes helps students to preserve the content of the lecture so that they can have it for later review as they prepare for class tests and quizzes (Mulligan & Kirkpatrick, 2000). In fact, a number of studies have reported significant correlations (i.e., from .42 [Fisher & Harris, 1973] to .53 [Boyle, 2010a; Titsworth, 2004]) between what students record in their notes from a lecture and their performance on recall measures and tests. Finally, although other variables (e.g., verbal memory, grade point average [GPA]) are useful predictors of school performance, the quality or quantity of notes (see Note 1) has been found to be a key predictor of test outcomes among older students (Peverly et al., 2007).

Of the specific problems that students with disabilities encounter while note-taking, Suritsky (1992) found that students with LD have a difficult time discerning important from unimportant lecture content, paying attention during lectures, and writing quickly enough to keep up with the lecture. Students’ difficulties are often reflected in their performance on measures of comprehension and recall, as well as the quality and quantity of notes recorded during lectures (Boyle, 2010a; Hughes & Suritsky, 1994). As for the quality of students’ notes, Boyle (2010a) found that middle school students with LD recorded only 18% of cued lecture points that were presented in the lecture, when compared with peers without disabilities, who recorded 42% of the cued lecture points. Overall, the notes of students with LD contained only half of the total lecture points when compared with the notes of peers without disabilities. With respect to the quantity of notes recorded, middle school students with LD recorded fewer notes than their peers without disabilities during lectures, recording an average of 57 words per note, compared with an average 130 words for nondisabled students (Boyle, 2010a). Finally, these differences in the amount of notes recorded were reflected in lower scores on measures of comprehension of lecture content (e.g., students with LD: 47%, nondisabled students: 67%; Boyle, 2010a).

Note-taking interventions for students in general education have been developed and assessed, with mixed results. For example, Palmatier (1971) trained high school students to use one of four note-taking techniques during lectures: outline notes, three-column Cornell notes, two-column notes, and traditional notes. The study results indicated no significant differences on achievement, with only the group that used the two-column method showing improvement in the quality of notes recorded from pre- to posttraining levels. In another study, Risch and Kiewra (1990) trained general education middle school students to use one of three note-taking techniques (traditional, linear, or matrix) during a lecture and, when they studied notes (e.g., their own notes or expert notes), across three measures (across-topic, within-topic, and application). The results concluded that matrix notes were more effective for female students who created them than for students studying from them. In addition, students who used the matrix notes on the application task scored higher than when using the other note-taking techniques.

sec.title: Study Purpose
sec.p: In response to the unique note-taking problems that students with LD and other high-incidence disabilities exhibit, several researchers (Boyle 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Evans, Pelham, & Grudberg, 1994–1995; Lazarus, 1991) developed and assessed note-taking techniques for these students. Although academic interventions (e.g., classroom learning strategies, mnemonic instruction, explicit instruction, study aids, graphic organizers) to improve student learning in secondary content areas for students with disabilities were examined in a previous meta-analysis (Scruggs, Mastropieri, Berkeley, & Graetz, 2010), specific note-taking techniques have not been thoroughly examined through a systematic review of the literature in the school-age population (Grades 3–12) of students with disabilities. Therefore, the purpose of the current systematic review was to answer the following two questions:

list-item.p: What research-based note-taking interventions for students with disabilities are available in the literature?
How effective are these interventions on measures of achievement and notes recorded?

sec.title: Method
sec.p: A three-step procedure was used to locate potential articles for inclusion in this systematic review (Gajria, Jitendra, Sood, & Sacks, 2007; Wexler, Vaughn, Edmonds, & Reutebuch, 2008). The following descriptors were used to identify potential studies: note(s), guided notes, note-taking (and notetaking), lecture, lecture notes, recording notes, strategic note, lecture learning, and content lecture. First, we conducted a search to locate studies between the years 1980 and 2010 in the following databases: Academic Search Complete, ERIC, MEDLINE, PAIS International, Periodicals Index Online, PsycINFO, Web of Science, and Wilson OmniFile Full Text. Whenever possible, searches were restricted to peer-reviewed journals in the disciplines of education and psychology between the years 1980 and 2010 and had to be in English. From this initial search, more than 9,000 abstracts were identified; however, many were duplications of other searchers or were not relevant to our review (e.g., recording notes in psychotherapy, recording notes when serving on a jury).

Second, we conducted a computer search through popular special education journals that were most representative of journals that publish research on students with disabilities: Education and Treatment of Children, Exceptional Children, Exceptionality, Journal of Applied Behavior Analysis, Journal of Behavioral Education, Journal of Learning Disabilities, Journal of School Psychology, Journal of Special Education, Learning Disability Quarterly, Psychology in the Schools, Remedial and Special Education, School Psychology Quarterly, School Psychology Review, and Teacher Education and Special Education. In all cases but one, we were able to go through each abstract and article title from the aforementioned journals from January 1980 to December 2010. In the case of Remedial and Special Education, we were only able to view each issue’s abstracts back through 1984 (see Note 2). Despite this extensive search, no new articles were found. Third, as was done in previous research (Gajria et al., 2007; Wexler et al., 2008), we performed an ancestral search through the references of identified articles and seminal articles on note-taking from special education and general education (Bretzing & Kulhavy, 1979; Di Vesta & Gray, 1972; Hartley & Davies, 1978; Hughes & Suritsky, 1994; Kiewra, 1985, 1989; Saski, Swicegood, & Carter, 1983) to locate any additional articles. From this review of the references, no new articles were identified.

sec.title: Selection Criteria
sec.p: Studies were selected if they met the following criteria:

sec.title: Search span
sec.p: The study appeared in a peer-refereed journal article between January 1980 and December 2010. The start date of 1980 was chosen because it was during this decade that the earliest articles began to appear in education- or psychology-refereed journals on the topic of note-taking for use during lectures for students with disabilities. For example, Saski et al. (1983) were the earliest authors to suggest the use of the columnar note-taking technique for students with LD. Even though the article was only descriptive in nature (and did not meet the criteria used here), it was nevertheless the earliest article to describe a note-taking technique for students with disabilities to use during lectures and, hence, 1980 served as the start date.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: The study utilized treatment-comparison, single-group, or single-subject designs were included. Previous syntheses and meta-analyses (Wexler et al., 2008; Xin & Jitendra, 1999) have examined topics that incorporated multiple design options, particularly when the unique nature of the independent variable (e.g., repeated readings, mathematical problem solving) allows for researchers to examine its effects over the short and long term.

sec.title: Grades 3 to 12 students with an identified disability
sec.p: The study included in its sample participants who were in Grades 3–12 and who had an identified disability. Although students with LD were the targeted population, in our search no disability areas were excluded. We chose Grade 3 as the starting grade because this was the lowest grade level identified in research studies that used a note-taking intervention (e.g., strategic note-taking) during lectures with the school-age population (Lee, Lan, Hamman, & Hendricks, 2008).

sec.title: Independent and dependent variables
sec.p: The study examined the effects of a note-taking technique or intervention (i.e., independent variable) that students used during teacher-led lectures on one or more measures (i.e., dependent variables) of achievement or notes. We purposefully limited the use of note-taking interventions to teacher-led lectures (i.e., those lectures where students are recording notes on new content). We did not include any studies that examined recording notes during reading activities because we felt that reading content via textbooks and listening to class lectures are two distinctly different activities, each of which has a different outcome and to which students with disabilities respond differently. Furthermore, the main focus of this synthesis was to examine the effects of note-taking interventions during teacher-led lectures in content areas.

sec.title: Coding Procedures
sec.p: Following the initial database search, the first author conducted a screening based on the descriptors and information found in the title and abstract. A similar procedure of identifying potential articles by examining each abstract and title has been used in prior syntheses (Gajria et al., 2007; Wexler et al., 2008). Because there were known studies that included college and high school students with disabilities within the same note-taking article, articles involving college students were retained for possible inclusion in the initial screening review. For example, the article of Lazarus (1993) contained the results of two studies. In the first study, high school students with LD or emotional/behavioral disabilities (EBD) were assessed on their use of guided notes; in the second study, college students with LD were assessed on their use of guided notes. This screening resulted in 52 potential articles, with many of these including college students. Once we examined either the abstract or the article and were able to identify the population with certainty, we were able to reduce the number of articles to 17 that used note-taking interventions with school-age populations.

From this list of 17, the first author and second author met, read each article, and determined whether each met all criteria. Any disagreements were resolved through discussion. Eight of the articles (Ayer & Milson, 1993; Bretzing, Kulhavy, & Caterino, 1987; Huffman & Spires, 1994; Lee et al., 2008; Palmatier, 1971; Peck & Hannafin, 1983; Peper & Mayer, 1986; Risch & Kiewra, 1990) were eliminated because although they used a note-taking intervention among general education populations, they did not include any students with disabilities. A ninth article (Mastropieri, Scruggs, Spencer, & Fontana, 2003) was also eliminated because of the manner in which the note-taking intervention was used. In the Mastropieri et al. (2003) study, students first read the chapter or sections of the chapter and then completed guided notes while the teacher circulated around the room and assisted students. Only after students completed the guided notes from their readings did the teacher review the guided notes on an overhead to ensure they were complete. In this case, we viewed guided notes as being used as a postreading activity rather than as a note-taking intervention that students with disabilities completed during class lectures. The end result of this final review was a total of nine studies that matched all of the criteria. These studies were then coded based on year, author(s), participant characteristics (e.g., disability, age, gender), setting, independent variable, comparison intervention, dependent variables, and results. Both authors constructed tables based on the coded variables. A comparison of the tables indicated 100% agreement.

sec.title: Effect Size (ES) Calculation
sec.p: ESs were calculated for experimental–control group, single-group, and single-subject research studies that provided sufficient statistical information. For experimental–control group studies, the ES was estimated using Hedges’s g, whereby the difference is derived by the average experimental group score minus the average control group score and divided by the pooled standard deviation. For the single-group studies, the difference was determined by the average posttest score minus the average pretest score divided by the pretest standard deviation (Becker, 1988). The effects of the one single-group study were computed using standardized pre–post mean differences and then converted to the g metric. In addition, some studies contained small sample sizes (i.e., less than 20 participants), causing the ES to be biased by overestimating the effects of the treatment (Cooper, 2010; Hedges, 1981). Therefore, in all of the studies in our synthesis, analyses were conducted using Hedges’s g because it represents a more conservative ES (Lipsey & Wilson, 2001). According to Cohen (1988), ESs can be interpreted as follows: ES = 0.20 (small), ES = 0.50 (medium), and ES = 0.80 (large). Finally, to determine the effects of single-subject research, percentage of nonoverlapping data (PND) was calculated (Scruggs & Mastropieri, 1998; Scruggs, Mastropieri, & Casto, 1987). In terms of the effectiveness using PND, Scruggs and Mastropieri (1998) reported that PND scores more than 90 (i.e., treatment data points that exceed highest baseline data point by 90%) are very effective; PND scores between 70 and 90 are effective; PND scores between 50 and 70 are questionable; and PND scores below 50 are considered ineffective. These guidelines were used because they are the only published guidelines available in the literature for deciding the effectiveness of PND methods.

sec.title: Characteristics of Data Set
sec.p: As previously noted, the final sample consisted of nine studies found in eight articles (Boyle, 2010b, Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Evans et al., 1994–1995, Hamilton, Seibert, Gardner, & Talbert-Johnson, 2000; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999). The Evans et al. (1994–1995) article contained two studies (i.e., Studies 1 and 2). Although the Lazarus (1993) article also described two studies (i.e., Study 1 with high school students with LD or EBD and Study 2 with college students with LD), Study 1 was retained, but Study 2 was omitted because it used college students. Hence, for future reference, Study 1 that involved high school students with disabilities will be referred to as Lazarus (1993). Of the nine studies, a total of 122 students were identified as having a disability. From this sample, 79 students (64.75%) had LD; 30 students (24.59%) had attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD); 8 students (6.56%) had EBD; 4 students (3.28%) had cognitive impairments (CI); and 1 student (0.82%) was identified as developmentally delayed (DD). In addition, 3 students without disabilities were also reported in the samples from the studies, with 2 students identified as English as a second language (ESL) and 1 student who had no disability (see Tables 1 and 2 in the “Results” section for each specific disability type per study). In seven of the nine studies in which gender was described, 75.5% of participants were male and 24.5% were female. In those studies that described the ethnicity of participants, 67.8% were European Americans, 19.3% were African Americans, 7.2% were Hispanic Americans, and 4.8% were Asian Americans. In six of the nine studies that reported intelligence scores, the average IQ score of all participants was 101.7. In the remaining three studies that did not report individual IQ scores of the participants, Hamilton et al. (2000) reported that IQ scores ranged from 81 to 119 for the 7 participants, Lazarus (1991) described the intelligence of the 6 participants with LD as being within the average range, and Sweeney et al. (1999) did not report intelligence of the 3 participants in their study.

sec.p: In all, five studies examined note-taking among high school-age students, three included middle school-age students, and one included elementary-age students. Middle to low socioeconomic standing was reported in two of the studies (Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999), with regional locations reported for five of the studies as urban (Lazarus, 1991, 1993–Study 1; Sweeney et al., 1999), rural (Boyle & Weishaar, 2001), or metropolitan (Boyle, 2010b). Finally, five studies took place in non–general education settings, such as a special education classroom (Boyle & Weishaar, 2001), a remedial summer school (Sweeney et al., 1999), a summer treatment program (Evans et al., 1994–1995, Studies 1 and 2), and a detention center (Hamilton et al., 2000), and four studies took place in general education or inclusive classrooms (Boyle, 2010b; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005). It should be noted that the one student with no identified disability was actually in a detention center; otherwise, this was the only student without disabilities reported by authors of the studies. In those studies that took place in inclusive or general education settings, the authors reported only the results of students with disabilities.

Of the nine studies, teachers used live lectures in 78% of the studies and videotaped lectures in 22% of them. History lectures were used in five of the studies and science lectures were used in the remaining four studies. The length of the typical lecture was 25 min, with lecture times varying from 15 to 30 min.

sec.title: Note-Taking Interventions for Students With LD and High-Incidence Disabilities
sec.p: In regards to the type of note-taking interventions used with students with disabilities, five studies used guided notes (Hamilton et al., 2000; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999), two studies used strategic note-taking (Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001), and two studies used directed note-taking activity (Evans et al., 1994–1995). Guided notes are teacher-prepared outlines of the lecture that are meant to guide students through the lecture. Guided notes provide students with an outline of the content from the lecture and contain designated spaces for students to record more detailed information about specific lecture points (Hamilton, et al., 2000; Lazarus, 1991). Researchers used several slightly different versions of guided notes. For example, Sweeney et al. (1999) created two versions of guided notes called short-form guided notes and long-form guided notes. Both forms used a cloze procedure in which the guided notes were missing essential words (i.e., student were provided with a blank space) that students would fill in as the teacher lectured. The short form was missing one to three essential words from the lecture and the long form was missing four to eight words. Patterson (2005) and Hamilton et al. (2000) used a format that was a combination of the aforementioned long and short form. Finally, the format for guided notes developed by Lazarus (1991, 1993) resembled more of a traditional outline that used roman numerals and uppercase letters, along with words or questions that corresponded to the lecture. Again, students were to fill in blanks or missing words with information from the lecture.

Although guided notes were developed using actual lecture content (i.e., content-specific notes that use words from lecture points to cue students to record notes), strategic note-taking provided students with cognitive prompts and cues (e.g., record three to six main lecture points, record new vocabulary, summarize lecture points) to assist them during note-taking (Boyle & Weishaar, 2001). Strategic note-taking paper was used with different lecture topics and, most recently, was used in conjunction with the CUES strategy (Boyle, 2010b) for students with LD. During the lecture, students used the prompts from the strategic note-taking paper to record notes from the lecture. For example, under the heading Name three to six new main points with details as they are being discussed, students recorded three to six lecture points; under the heading New vocabulary or terms, students recorded vocabulary words from that section of the lecture; and under the heading Summary—Quickly describe how the ideas are related, students summarized the three to six lecture points. These prompts were repeated on several more pages until the lecture ended. On the last page of the strategic note-taking paper under the written prompt Write five important lecture points and describe the details of each lecture point, students wrote down five important lecture points. The components of the CUES strategy consisted of the following: Cluster step was used to prompt students to record three to six ideas on the strategic note-taking paper; the Use step prompted students to listen for teacher cues (i.e., number cues and importance cues) and on hearing these cues, record the lecture points that were associated with the cues; the Enter step prompted students to enter vocabulary words in their notes; and the Summarize step prompted students to write a word or words that would categorize the three to six lecture points that they had listed (i.e., clustered together) in their notes.

Finally, the directed note-taking activity (Spires & Stone, 1989) involved embedding note-taking skills within lectures and slowly teaching these note-taking skills to students over time (e.g., 3–6 weeks). Directed note-taking incorporated the following three components: the split-page format for recording notes; the use of self-questions for students to use before, during, and after the lecture; and explicit strategy instruction through teacher modeling, guided practice, and independent practice. In the split-page method, the left column was used for main concepts of the lecture and the right column was used for recording definitions, details, and examples as they are related to the main concepts (Spires & Stone, 1989). During the lecture, “the teacher explained the rationale for each note as he or she presented it in the context of the lecture” (Evans et al., 1994–1995, p. 3).

sec.title: Note-taking intervention instruction
sec.p: The average length of note-taking training per study was approximately two sessions (range = 1–3 sessions), except for the Evans et al. (1994–1995) study, in which training sessions were 3 weeks in length. The note-taking training varied depending on the technique and researcher. In the studies by Lazarus (1991, 1993), students with LD were taught over three consecutive periods by their classroom teacher (science or history teacher). During the first training session, students were taught to recognize main ideas and key terms. The teacher reviewed these on a transparency, and students learned to differentiate between them. During the second training session, students completed guided notes as they listened to two 10-min audiotaped lectures. During the third training session, the teacher lectured using notes recorded on transparencies, as students completed their own guided notes. When finished, guided notes were evaluated and students were provided with reinforcement and corrective feedback. Patterson (2005) reported that she instructed students with LD and EBD how to complete guided notes, provided them time to practice using guided notes, and once students demonstrated proficiency, provided them with guided notes to use during lectures. Likewise, Hamilton et al. (2000) taught students with LD to complete guided notes during one class period; when students demonstrated proficiency, they provided students with guided notes to use in the remaining sessions. Finally, Sweeney et al. (1999) did not describe training procedures; instead, prior to students’ use of guided notes (i.e., long and short form), students were simply instructed to fill in the blanks with words from the overhead transparency.

In the Boyle and Weishaar (2001) study, students with LD and CI were taught to use strategic note-taking. During the first session, the researcher described and modeled how to use strategic note-taking while playing a videotaped training lecture. During the training, the researcher periodically stopped the lecture to check students’ notes and provided feedback. During the second session, students were shown the same videotaped lecture and recorded notes using new strategic note-taking paper; however, during the second session, the videotape was played in its entirety to acclimate students to the pace of a typical lecture. Boyle (2010b) not only taught students with LD in a similar manner but also integrated the previously mentioned CUES strategic note-taking strategy into the training sessions.

In the Evans et al. (1994–1995) study, students with ADHD were taught directed note-taking. In Study 1, during the 1st week, the teacher presented notes on an overhead and students recorded notes in their usual manner. During the 2nd and 3rd weeks, the teacher began using directed note-taking with students. As notes were presented on the overhead, the teacher (a) explained why some notes were main ideas and others were details and (b) told students to record the notes “exactly as they appeared on the overhead” (Evans et al., 1994–1995, p. 5). During the 4th week, the teacher interrupted the lecture and asked students to generate their own ideas for notes. These notes were written on the transparency by the teacher and recorded in their notebooks by the students. During the 5th week, the teacher discussed the main ideas of lecture but only recorded details on the overhead transparency for students to record. In Week 6 of the training, the teacher discussed and wrote down only the main ideas for students to record and discussed the details of these ideas (but did not record them on the transparency). In the 7th week, the teacher did not write down any notes and instead only answered questions about notes. This instruction was followed by 1 week of training during which the students were assessed on their ability to record notes independently. In Study 2, the authors used the same training procedures but condensed them from 6 weeks to 3 weeks.

sec.title: Teacher and researcher instruction
sec.p: Teachers taught students to use the note-taking procedures in four of the studies (Evans et al., 1994–1995, Studies 1 and 2; Lazarus, 1991, 1993), researchers trained students in four of the studies (Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Hamilton et al., 2000; Patterson, 2005), and in one study it was not clear how students were trained to use guided notes (Sweeney et al., 1999). Lazarus (1991, 1993) taught teachers over three 1-hr sessions, and these teachers then instructed students over three sessions. In the Evans et al. (1994–1995) study, there was no mention of how the teacher was taught by researchers to use the directed note-taking procedure. It is interesting to note that in the one study (Hamilton et al., 2000) in which guided notes had the lowest/least effect (i.e., PND) on quiz scores, students were taught in only one session.

sec.title: Review of notes
sec.p: Seven of the nine studies incorporated a review or study session, typically 10 min in length, as part of its note-taking procedures. Studies that used guided notes with study or review sessions often found a gain in achievement when students studied/reviewed notes (Lazarus, 1991, 1993). For example, when a 10-min review period was incorporated in the study, Lazarus (1991) found an average 24% gain in test scores than when students with LD used guided notes alone. Similarly, in a second study, Lazarus (1993) found an average increase of 24% in the portion of the study when students with LD used a 10-min review compared with when students used guided notes without a review. Although guided notes with study/review sessions produced an increase in achievement scores, directed note-taking that incorporated the use of a study hall period (Evans et al., 1994–1995) produced only slight increases (e.g., 4% increase in study hall assignments scores when students used notes in study hall).

sec.title: Design and measures
sec.p: Of the nine studies, five were single-subject design (Hamilton et al., 2000; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999), two used a single-group design (Evans et al., 1994–1995, Studies 1 and 2), and two were experimental group design (Boyle, 2010b: Boyle & Weishaar, 2001).

Although every study assessed student performance using teacher-made tests or quizzes (measures varied from 10 to 30 items in length), the type of questions that were used varied from measure to measure. A consideration of the type of questions used is important because previous research has found that the effects of note-taking differ on recognition tests (e.g., multiple choice, fill-in-the-blank) compared with free recall tests (e.g., essay), with students who recorded notes exhibiting slightly larger ESs on free recall measures (Kobayashi, 2005). The belief is that a recognition test provides lots of retrieval cues that make it easier for non–note-takers to retrieve the correct information, thus reducing the difference in scores between note-takers and non–note-takers (Craik & Tulving, 1975; Kahana, 1996). Six of the nine studies (Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001, Hamilton et al., 2000; Lazarus, 1993; Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999) used multiple-choice questions as part of their assessment. The other types of test/quiz questions included fill-in-the-blank, true/false, matching, and short answer, although the exact number of each type was not described in several of the studies (Evans et al., 1994–1995; Hamilton et al., 2000; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999). In addition to teacher-made tests or quizzes, other achievement measures that were administered to students included both immediate free recall and long-term free recall measures (Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001).

Finally, in seven of the studies, researchers assessed either the quality (i.e., accuracy) or quantity of students’ notes (i.e., number of words or lecture points; Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Evans et al., 1994–1995; Hamilton et al., 2000; Patterson, 2005; Sweeney et al., 1999). Although quality and quantity of notes are effective indicators of achievement, it may not be necessary to assess both because according to Peverly et al. (2007), each is highly correlated (.93) with the other.

sec.title: Outcome measures
sec.p: Using the procedures outlined by Scruggs and Mastropieri (1998) and Scruggs et al. (1987), we calculated PNDs, which are presented in Table 1. Of the single-subject studies that assessed the effects of note-taking on students with LD, the mean PND for achievement for the five studies was 84.06%, with a range of 45.43% (Hamilton et al., 2000) to 100% (Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005). In particular, three studies involving students with LD (Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005) had PNDs of 100% across baseline to guided notes phases and baseline to guided notes plus review phases, indicating a very effective treatment effect (Scruggs & Mastropieri, 1998). In the Sweeney et al. (1999) study, PNDs were similar between the short form (PND = 77.78%) and the long form (PND = 71.97%), indicating that the short form appeared to be slightly more effective than the long form. Finally, one guided notes study (Hamilton et al., 2000) that examined the effects of guided notes with students with LD had an average PND falling below 50% on quiz scores. In fact, four of the seven students from this study had individual PNDs falling below 50%, whereas the other three students had PNDs of 55%, 60%, and 70%. According to Scruggs and Mastropieri (1998), studies with PND scores between 50 and 70 are considered questionable and below 50% are considered ineffective. Overall, four of the five studies in this synthesis reached or exceeded the effective level and one study had average PNDs that indicated that the guided notes treatment was ineffective.

Table 2 lists the ES for the four other studies. In Studies 1 and 2 of Evans et al. (1994–1995), the researchers used a pretest/posttest single-group design to examine the effects of directed note-taking on students with ADHD. In Study 1, the authors listed quiz scores and assignments scores as dependent variables; however, they did not include these scores as part of their analysis because they felt that “there were too many factors (e.g., time) that may have contributed to changes in these measures” (Evans et al., 1994–1995, p. 8). In Study 2, the researchers incorporated four conditions:

list-item.p: Control condition: No notes were taken in class and no notes were used in the study hall;
Treatment 1 condition: Notes were recorded by students in class using directed note-taking, but they were not permitted to use those notes in study hall;
Treatment 2 condition: No notes were recorded by students, but teacher notes were provided to students to study in study hall; and
Treatment 3 condition: Notes were recorded by students in class using directed note-taking, and students used these notes to study in study hall.

sec.p: Because this was a single-group design study, students served as their own controls. The outcomes were assessed through a quiz score (20-item quiz) and a study hall assignment score (15-item assignment). According to the authors of the study, of the quiz score and study hall assignments, the note-taking intervention (Treatments 1 and 3 conditions) was statistically significant for only study hall assignments. Furthermore, average assignment scores were higher when students either took notes using directed note-taking or used notes in the study hall. In our analysis, for the two comparisons dealing with note-taking and assignment scores, we found ESs of 0.37 when students used directed note-taking but did not use those notes in study hall, and 0.54 when students used directed note-taking and used notes in study hall.

For the two experimental studies that used random assignment of students with LD and CI to treatments, Boyle and Weishaar (2001) reported a difference on a multiple-choice test between (a) students with LD and CI who used strategic note-taking and (b) students who used conventional note-taking (control group students who recorded notes on lined paper), favoring the treatment group. ES for this comparison was 0.82 for test scores, indicating a large ES. For the recall measures, these authors reported that treatment students who used strategic note-taking exhibited higher scores than students in the control group. Results from our analysis revealed ESs of 1.17 for immediate free recall and 1.43 for long-term free recall measures, indicating large ESs for both recall measures (Cohen, 1988). In the Boyle (2010b) study, treatment students with LD who used strategic note-taking scored slightly higher on the test than control students. The ES from our analysis was 0.70, reflecting a medium ES.

sec.title: Effects on the quality and quantity of notes
sec.p: Six of the studies (Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Evans et al., 1994–1995; Hamilton et al., 2000; Patterson, 2005, Sweeney et al., 1999) provided information about the quality or quantity of notes recorded by students. Of the three single-subject design studies (Hamilton et al., 2000; Patterson, 2005, Sweeney et al., 1999) that reported on the accuracy of notes for students with LD, researchers found an increase in accuracy from baseline (M = 41.83%) to guided notes (M = 77.42%) phases that led to an average improvement in accuracy of 35.59% among students with disabilities. Of interest, Sweeney et al. (1999) reported that students improved their accuracy the most on the guided notes short form (60.17%) compared with the long form (44.94%).

Evans et al. (1994–1995) found that the quantity of notes improved from an average pretest condition of 68.6% of details that students with ADHD recorded in notes to 85.9% in the posttest condition (i.e., ES = 1.02). However, when these same notes were examined, students recorded fewer main ideas from pretest (i.e., average = 74.2%) to posttest (i.e., average = 71.7%) conditions. The authors of the study concluded that students did indeed record main ideas during the posttest phase but did not record them as main ideas using the note-taking’s format. Boyle and Weishaar (2001) reported that high school students with LD and CI in the treatment group who used strategic note-taking recorded approximately 175 words in their notes, compared with students in the control group, who recorded 62 words, illustrating a large ES (3.06). Likewise, Boyle (2010b) reported that middle school students with LD who used strategic note-taking recorded an average of 108 words in notes compared with students with LD, who used conventional note-taking and recorded an average of 41 words (ES = 1.53).

sec.title: Effects on other measures
sec.p: In addition to examining the effects of note-taking interventions on measures of accuracy, quantity, comprehension, and recall, researchers also examined the effects on rates of on-task and disruptive behaviors (Evans et al., 1994–1995), vocabulary (Boyle & Weishaar, 2001), and different types of lecture points (e.g., cued and total lecture points) recorded by students (Boyle, 2010b). Evans et al. (1994–1995) reported that the better the quality of notes (e.g., more details, clarity, legibility, sequencing), the more likely students were to be on-task and the less likely to exhibit disruptive behavior. These researchers also found some modest positive correlations between note-taking and other variables, including details in notes and on-task rates (.47) and quality of notes and on-task rates (.42). Conversely, they found an inverse relationship between the quality of notes and disruptive behavior (−.41). Boyle and Weishaar (2001) examined vocabulary to determine whether students’ notes were associated with lecture content or recording unrelated words. The results of this portion of their study mirrored the findings from the total word count, and the authors reported that students who used strategic note-taking outperformed students who used conventional note-taking on both recall measures, as well as total vocabulary recorded in notes. Last, as far as the type of lecture points recorded and recalled, Boyle (2010b) found that students who used strategic note-taking recorded more cued lecture points and that overall, these students recorded more total lecture points in notes. Moreover, students also recalled more cued lecture points on immediate and long-term recall measures.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In general, the results indicated that students with LD and other disabilities who were taught to use note-taking techniques performed better on tests and quizzes (i.e., than using conventional note-taking), with the majority of studies showing very effective results or medium to large ESs on these measures. Of the three techniques (i.e., guided notes, strategic note-taking, and directed note-taking activity), guided notes and strategic note-taking were effective, as evidenced by PND or ES, at increasing student achievement on tests and quizzes, with the Hamilton et al. (2000) single-subject design study being the exception. Directed note-taking, however, was effective only with assignments scores. In addition, teaching note-taking techniques increased the accuracy of notes for students with developmental delays (Sweeney et al., 1999, had an average 92% PND), increased the number of words recorded in notes for students with LD (Boyle, 2010b, ES = 1.53; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001, ES = 3.06), and increased the number of details recorded in notes for students with ADHD (Evans et al., 1994–1995, ES = 1.02). Finally, note-taking interventions helped students with LD to record more key lecture points in notes and, in turn, recall more key lecture points on measures of immediate and long-term recall (Boyle, 2010b).

Although note-taking techniques were effective for the majority of studies, only two studies (Lazarus, 1991, 1993) assessed and documented the effects of a review session on comprehension. As mentioned previously, the use of review sessions increased quiz scores when compared with guided-notes-only sessions. These studies corroborate the results of other studies that found large ESs (ES = 0.75 and 0.77; Kobayashi, 2005) for the effects of note-taking plus review sessions strategy on comprehension among students without disabilities.

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: There were several limitations to this synthesis. First, the small numbers of research-based studies that we were able to locate limits the generalization of note-taking techniques for students with disabilities. Relatedly, the small number of studies also makes it difficult to say which note-taking technique is most effective. Including other studies, such as dissertations or ERIC documents (e.g., papers presented at conferences), might have increased the size of our analysis. A second limitation is the small number of students with certain types of disabilities included in our synthesis. Although the majority of students were those with LD, generalizing to students with other types of disabilities is cautioned because of the small number of disability types (i.e., eight students with EBD, four students with CIs) included in this synthesis.

sec.title: Implications for Future Research
sec.p: Future research should examine the effects of popular but untested forms of note-taking, such as Cornell notes (e.g., split page), mapping notes, and matrix notes. Although some of these types have been examined with students in general education during lectures (Palmatier, 1971; Risch & Kiewra, 1990), they remain untested among students with disabilities. In addition, future research should examine the effects of different types of note-taking interventions with different question types and learning tasks. For example, are certain types of note-taking more effective on application types of questions or essay questions? In addition, student note-taking interventions should compare providing students with the teacher’s complete notes during the lecture with providing them after the lecture for later review to see which is more effective on achievement measures. Finally, it is still unclear whether students who use guided notes (a) actually learn note-taking skills (Lazarus, 1991) and (b) can become autonomous learners once the teacher stops providing them with guided notes. Likewise, the generalization of other techniques (i.e., strategic note-taking and directed note-taking) has yet to be demonstrated. Future studies should examine how well these techniques generalize to inclusive or general education classrooms.

sec.title: Implications for the Classroom
sec.p: The note-taking techniques mentioned in this synthesis provide teachers of students with LD with note-taking interventions to use in content-area classroom lectures. What the synthesis highlights is that when teaching students to use note-taking interventions, teachers should use explicit and direct instruction that includes modeling, guided practice, and independent practice. These procedures were used throughout the studies and appeared to be crucial for teaching students with LD and other disabilities (Boyle, 2010b; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Evans et al., 1994–1995; Hamilton et al., 2000; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005). In these studies, researchers/teachers used two to three sessions to instruct students how to use note-taking procedures, during which they reviewed the note-taking form (e.g., guided notes, strategic note-taking paper) and important components of note-taking (e.g., recording main ideas, important terms or vocabulary, teacher cued notes), modeled how to record notes using the form, and provided students with opportunities to use the note-taking form during lectures that included feedback and reinforcement for correctly recording notes using the form (e.g., guided notes, strategic note-taking). Because the teacher would want to model the proper use of note-taking, a videotaped or audiotaped lecture, similar to a typical classroom lecture, might be useful during training sessions, as was done in previous studies (Boyle, 2010; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Lazarus, 1991, 1993). Using a videotaped lecture, the teacher can periodically stop, check notes, and provide students with feedback (Boyle, 2010; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001). Furthermore, the teacher could replay portions of the lecture that students failed to record, particularly those sections of the lecture that contain important information (i.e., cued lecture points) that students should have recorded in their notes. Finally, once students are proficient with the note-taking technique, a videotaped lecture from content classes could help students become acclimated to the pace of lectures in their actual classes, as was illustrated in those studies including students with LD (Boyle, 2010; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Lazarus, 1991, 1993).

The specific skills that students with LD should learn include listening for and grouping together similar lecture points or main ideas, recording important vocabulary with definitions, discerning between important and unimportant lecture points, recognizing lecture cues used by teachers (i.e., these may vary from teacher to teacher), using abbreviations and a common rule for abbreviating long words, and keeping notes in an organized format (Boyle, 2010; Boyle & Weishaar, 2001; Evans et al., 1994–1995; Hamilton et al., 2000; Hughes & Suritsky, 1994; Lazarus, 1991, 1993; Patterson, 2005).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Students with LD should begin learning note-taking skills in upper elementary grades as teachers can show them the advantages of writing down and recording important information (Lee et al., 2008). It is particularly important that students with LD learn how to record notes in middle and high school, where lectures become a common format used by teachers during class instruction (Olson, 2004; Putnam et al., 1993). Moreover, because a large number of students with LD and other mild disabilities will be attending postsecondary institutions, where lectures are used on almost a daily basis (Brobst, 1996; Newman, Wagner, Cameto, & Knokey, 2009), these students must learn effective note-taking skills. For students with LD, note-taking is a critical learning tool that is commonly used in classes from elementary school through college, for a variety of tasks (i.e., from research papers to class discussions), and by individuals throughout their lifetime.
